mdRecord.dcterms:title: Soissons Cathedral Basilica, exterior
Basilique Cathédrale Saint-Gervais-et-Saint-Protais de Soissons
Cathedral of Saints Gervasius and Protasius
Cathedrale de Soissons
mdRecord.dcterms:creator: Wilson, Richard Guy [photographer]
mdRecord.dcterms:publisher: Rector and Visitors of the University of Virginia
mdRecord.dcterms:description: Decorative detail at arch impost, west (entrance) facade

The construction of the south transept was begun about 1177, and the lowest courses of the choir in 1182. The choir with its original three-storey elevation and extremely tall clerestory was completed in 1211. This was earlier than Chartres, on which the design was supposed to have been based. Work then continued into the nave until the late 13th century. The single western tower dates from the mid-13th century and is an imitation of those of Notre Dame de Paris, which it equals in height (66 m, or 216 ft). A matching tower on the other side of the façade was originally planned, but never built. -- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soissons_Cathedral [work]
